thread.title: Millwall 1-0 Leicester: Shaun Cummings strike helps 10-man Lions down Foxes - 5 things we learned
thread.title_full: Millwall 1-0 Leicester: Shaun Cummings strike helps 10-man Lions down Foxes - 5 things we learned

author: Adrian Kajumba
title: Millwall 1-0 Leicester: Shaun Cummings strike helps 10-man Lions down Foxes - 5 things we learned
text:
Shaun Cummings strikes to win it for the Lions (Photo: Clive Rose) Share   
Ten-man Millwall continued their brilliant FA Cup run by claiming a third Premier League scalp to reach the quarter-finals. 
After already dumping out Bournemouth and Watford, Millwall shrugged off the dismissal of defender Jake Cooper to grab a last-minute winner from right-back Shaun Cummings and heap more misery on Claudio Ranieri and Premier League champions Leicester Leicester. 
Cooper was sent off after being shown two yellow cards either side of the break and Millwall were indebted to keeper Jordan Archer for keeping them in the tie. 
Archer reacted quickly to turn away Shinji Okazaki's first half header before producing a brilliant block to deny the Leicester striker when he seemed certain to score, minutes from the end. 
And Archer's heroics paved the way for Cummings to win the match at the death after he raced onto Lee Gregory's chest down and kept his cool to score. Jake Cooper is sent off for the hosts (Photo: Ian Walton) Shinji Okazaki battles with Calum Butcher (Photo: Clive Rose) Danny Simpson and Islam Slimani join the Foxes faithful in the away end (Photo: Plumb Images) 1. Boys at the back do it for Millwall 
This was a huge effort from Millwall to reach the last-eight and their goalkeeper and right back were the heroes. Jordan Archer produced some vital stops to keep Leicester at bay. 
The former Tottenham keeper's two stops from Shinji Okazaki were excellent. Then Shaun Cummings showed the poise and composure of a striker to score the winner at the death. 
In contrast to his calm, his goal sparked absolute bedlam at the Den and a pitch invasion that went on for ages despite the desperate pleas of the PA announcer. Andy King challenges Calum Butcher (Photo: Plumb Images) Fred Onyedinma defends the ball against Nampalys Mendy (Photo: Ian Walton) 2. Time to move on from Mendy signing 
At what point do you give up on a move that is proving difficult to pull off and try something else, possibly a bit simpler? 
It was something I wondered while watching Nampalys Mendy repeatedly give the ball away in the first half. 
Mendy tried four cross field passes from right to left and made an absolute mess of each one. 
He under hit the first two to Millwall players, slipped as he tried a third time, again giving the ball away and gifted Milwall position with a final fourth attempt. 
Finally he decided to just stick to the basics and keep the ball on the ground and was much more successful in helping Leicester keep possession. LONDON, ENGLAND - FEBRUARY 18: Demarai Gray of Leicester City in action with Calum Butcher of Millwall during of The Emirates FA Cup Fifth Round tie between Millwall and Leicester City at The Den on February 18, 2017 in London, England. (Photo by Plumb Images/Leicester City FC via Getty Images) (Photo: Plumb Images) 3. Wague survives baptism of fire 
This was a significant test for Leicester defender Molla Wague on his debut following his loan move from Udinese. 
A bobbly pitch, hostile crowd and a difficult opponent to deal with in Fred Onyedinma. 
He made a shaky start against the Millwall youngster, giving away a free-kick for fouling him and then letting Onyedinma wriggle clear of him to send over a cross that caused panic. 
But there were plus points too from the Mali stopper. He was strong and confident in the air, read the game well and it was also noticeable that once he quickly found his feet he realised this was not a place to take risks and duly didn't. 
His afternoon was cut short though when he went off with a shoulder injury after the break. LONDON, ENGLAND - FEBRUARY 18: Manager Claudio Ranieri of Leicester City during The Emirates FA Cup Fifth Round tie between Millwall and Leicester City at The Den on February 18, 2017 in London, England. (Photo by Plumb Images/Leicester City FC via Getty Images) (Photo: Plumb Images) 4. Lions show fight after red card 
Jake Cooper's red card could really have damaged Milwall's hopes. He got sent off after 51 minutes after being shown two yellow cards. Both of them could and probably should have been avoided. 
The first came when he tried to boot the ball out of Leicester goalkeeper Ron-Robert Zieler's hands in a first-half.Then he wiped out Ahmed Musa on the halfway line. 
Credit to Millwall though. They didn't fold and were actually even more of a threat after going down to 10 men. 
That says a lot about the spirit in Neil Harris's squad. LONDON, ENGLAND - FEBRUARY 18: Bartosz Kapustka of Leicester City in action with Shaun Williams of Millwall during The Emirates FA Cup Fifth Round tie between Millwall and Leicester City at The Den on February 18, 2017 in London, England. (Photo by Plumb Images/Leicester City FC via Getty Images) (Photo: Plumb Images) 5. Ranieri shows where his priorities lie 
Despite seeing how dangerous it was to make wholesale changes in the last round, Claudio Ranieri ignored those warning signs at Millwall. 
He made 10 to Leicester side for their trip to the League One side. 
Only Demarai Gray survived from the side well beaten by Swansea 2-0. 
In fairness to Ranieri the cup is his last on his list of priorities. 
The Foxes are in real relegation danger in the Premier League after sliding down the table and also have the small matter of a Champions League last-16 tie against Sevilla coming up on Wednesday. LONDON, ENGLAND - FEBRUARY 18: Andy King of Leicester City in action with Aiden O'Brian of Millwall during The Emirates FA Cup Fifth Round tie between Millwall and Leicester City at The Den on February 18, 2017 in London, England. (Photo by Plumb Images/Leicester City FC via Getty Images) (Photo: Plumb Images) poll loading Is the FA Cup still the greatest cup competition in the world? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
